Description: This virtual tour tells the history of the Yolo Basin Foundation and the geography of the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.
Description 2: Scroll through the multimedia narrative and explore the accomanying map layers, or use the buttons to jump to a particular chapter.

Description: The Central Valley, California's agricultural heartland, is an 18,000-square-mile sedimentary valley, fed by vast watershed of the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers.
Description 2: The valley's drainage area extends to the crests of the Sierra Nevada and the coast range, a catchment for rain and snowmelt that encompasses 60,000 square miles. Water from the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers and their tributaries converge at the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta--a highly modified landscape of tidal sloughs and canals surrounding levee-protected agricultural lowlands--before flowing out to sea via the San Francisco Bay.

Description: Prior to Euro-American settlement, the Central Valley was a complex mosaic of grasslands and riparian valley oak forests, transitioning to freshwater wetlands and tidal channels at the Delta.
Description 2: Zoom in to see a detailed map of the Delta from a historical ecology study by the San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI), which indicates a combination of freshwater emergent wetland and seasonal wet meadows at the location of today's Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. Distributary channels once branched out from Putah Creek to spread water into the wetlands and meadows.

Description: As early as the mid-1800s, earthen flood control levees were constructed to support farming in the Delta. Growing populations in the Sacramento Valley were vulnerable to rising river levels from winter storms and spring snowmelt.

In 1917, the US Congress authorized the Sacramento River Flood Control Project, a system of levees and weirs that directed flood waters away from developed areas and into the designated undeveloped Sutter and Yolo bypasses.
Media Credit: Animated overview of the Sacramento River Flood Control System produced by the US Army Corps of Engineers

Description: The 92-square-mile Yolo Bypass begins at Fremont Weir, along the Sacramento River just northwest of the City of Sacramento, and extends south to the Delta.
Description 2: In wet winters, water from the Sacramento River rises high enough to spill over the Fremont Weir and flood the Yolo Bypass. The California Department of Water Resources can open and close the Sacramento Weir to let in additional water from the Sacramento River (and, during floods, the American River). The bypass also receives perennial inflow from Cache Creek and Putah Creek to its west.

Description: extent of flooding over different years

The Yolo Bypass is an important stop along the Pacific Flyway, a north-south migratory pathway along which hundreds of millions of birds travel each year. Sacramento Valley wetlands are critical overwintering habitat for waterfowl that then return to the Canadian Arctic for the summer.
Description 2: The lines on this map are GPS tracks of migratory ducks and geese collected by the USGS Dixon Field Station.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: However, by the 1990s, over XX% of Sacramento Valley wetland habitat had been lost, converted to agricultural and urban uses.
Description 2:

Chapter: Founding the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area
Description: Feb 1990: Yolo Basin Working Group sponsors a meeting with area landowners at the California Trucking Association Building in West Sacramento to discuss the proposal for a Yolo Basin Wildlife Area.
Feb 1990: Yolo Basin Foundation founded
Dec 1991: State Wildlife Conservation Board completes purchase of approximately 3100 acres at the Putah Creek Sinks from PG&E Properties, Inc. for $4.57 million. - Funded by 1988 Proposition 70
Notes: show the putah ck sinks overlay

Description: Apr 1992: Final Environmental Assessment/Project Modification Report for Yolo Basin Wetlands project is released by U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. (opportunity for overlay?) 17 Aug 1995: Ground Breaking Celebration is held at Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. Over 150 people attend morning ceremonies.
Nov 1993: Comprehensive resource inventory completed. (opportunity for overlay?)
Feb 1994 First duck days held
17 Aug 1995: Ground Breaking Celebration is held at Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. Over 150 people attend morning ceremonies.
Nov 1995 First phase of construction completed - 400 acres of ponds in NW section and 400 acres of ponds in SW section. Pintails are observed the next month during christmas bird coutn.

15 Nov 1997: President Clinton, Congressman Vic Fazio, John Garamendi, Assistant Deputy Director of US Dept. of the Interior, John Zhirsky, Assistant Secretary of Civil Works for US Army Corps of Engineers, Doug Wheeler, Secretary of State Resources Agency, Richard Rominger, Assistant Secretary of US Dept. of Agriculture and 800 other supporters attended a rainy but festive opening celebration of the completion of the Yolo Basin Wetlands Project and the transfer of the YBWA from the Corps of Engineers to State Dept. of Fish and Game.
Aug 1998: Demonstration Wetland irrigation is installed and 400 trees planted. First flood up of demonstration wetlands occurs.
Dec 2001: Purchase of 12,000 additional acres including the Causeway Ranch, Los Rios Farms properties, Giverson Ranch and Tule Ranch, expanding the Wildlife Area to 16,000 acres.
The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area is actively managed to balance the parallel goals of flood protection, agriculture, and wildlife conservation.
Description 2: In this section, we will learn about the mosaic of different land uses in the Wildlife Area, and the way they change seasonally throughout the year. This map outlines the fields and ponds that make up the Wildlife Area, colored by their uses.

Description: Permanent ponds, 4 to 5 feet deep, are filled with water year-round.
Description 2: These ponds provide year-round habitat for the area's resident waterfowl, including those that nest in the wildlife area during the summer: coots, mallards, galwalls, and cinnamon teal. Green's Lake in the northeast is a remnant oxbow lake that dates back to the pre-development Sacramento River Valley.

Description: Seasonal wetlands are shallower, 6-18 inches deep. These ponds, planted with tule and cattail, are filled with water in the fall through spring.
Description 2: Wetlands are flooded in September/October to provide wintering habitat for large numbers of migratory waterfowl.

Description: Seasonal wetlands are drained in April before invasive weeds can establish. They are restored, seeded and irrigated over the summer prior to the next fall inundation.
Description 2: Some wetlands are first partially-drained ot provide shallow spring shorebird habitat.

Description: Putah Creek flows into the wildlife area from the west, carrying water from Lake Berryessa.
Description 2: The creek eventually flows into the toe drain that runs alongside the levee of the Sacramento Deep Water Ship Canal, and out to the Delta.

Description: Stretches of riparian woodland and scrub line water bodies including Putah Creek and Green's Lake.
Description 2: Trees such as cottonwood, willow, oregon ash, box elder, and blue elderberry support land mammals and nesting birds of prey.

Description: Alongside dedicated wetlands, the Wildlife Area also supports 2,400 acres of rice cultivation.
Description 2: Rice is planted in May-June and harvested in September. This collaboration between local rice growers and the state helps with land management costs and creates bird friendly habitat.

Description: After the harvest, starting in November, the rice fields are flooded to provide additional expanses of wetland habitat for migratory waterfowl and shorebirds.
Description 2: Fields are eventually drained the next March as migratory waterfowl and shorebirds begin to head north, to prepare for the next season's harvest.
Media Credit: add video of birds in flooded rice fields

Description: Rice farmers are required to set aside two parcels of land for summertime shorebird habitat.
Description 2: These areas are flooded in succession in July and August to provide the shallow water foraging habitat preferred by migrating shorebirds returning to the wildlife area in late summer..

Description: About 5,000 acres of irrigated and dryland pasture provide upland habitat alongside grazing range.
Description 2: The bypass also includes upland agriculture uses including tomatoes, sunflower, safflower, corn, and milo.

Description: The southern grasslands of the wildlife area include rare vernal pool formations--ephemeral wetlands formed in shallow depressions that fill throughout the rainy season.
Description 2: As they dry in the spring, characteristic rings of wildflowers form along the receding shoreline in response to changing soil moisture. Flowers include goldfields, miniature lupine, butter-and-eggs, dowingia, monkey flower, and tidy tips.
Media Credit: Vernal pools and the umbrella barn at Glide Tule Ranch © Skyler Lewis

Description: (Slavich slough)
The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area is located off Interstate 80 between Davis and Sacramento.
Description 2: Take exit 78 from I-80 to visit the wildlife area (just east of the exit) and the headquarters (2 miles west on Chiles Rd).

Description: Take advantage of the popular auto tour loop for year-round wildlife viewing that passes through permanent ponds, seasonal wetlands, and rice fields.
Several hiking trails are accessible year round.
Description 2: Get out of the car at Parking Lot C and take the loop along the Tule Trail to see seasonal wetlands to the west and permanent ponds to the east.

Description: In the late fall and winter, the Wildlife Area is a hunting destination.
Description 2: Duck hunting season begins in October and extends through January, while pheasant season begins mid-November. The hunting area begins at a check-point and is separate from the year-round public wildlife viewing zone.

Description: Outside of hunting season, expanded public access begins in February. Catch the tail end of the migratory waterfowl season, and the bountiful shorebird display in the spring.
Description 2: These trails are open until hunting begins again in October.

Description: The demonstration wetlands at the headquarters are as start of field trips to the wildlife area and other local destinations like grasslands.
Description 2: More details here- show demo wetland
More details here- show demo wetland

Description: The Yolo Basin Foundation's outdoor ecucation program, Discover the Flyway, hosted 60,000 students in its first decade (1997-2017).
Description 2: More details here

Description: Bats under the flyway
Glide tule ranch vernal pool and wildflower tours
Engagement with the arts

The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area hosts a diverse range of bird species that vary from season to season: ducks and geese that migrate long distances to the bypass in the winter, spring shorebirds foraging in shallow wetlands, summer nesting waterfowl and year-round residents, blackbirds flocking among tule reeds, and birds of prey hunting overhead.
Description 2: This section describes some of the common birds seen at the Wildlife Area. For a full list, take a look at the bird observations on eBird.

Description: Spectacular numbers of wintering waterfowl come to the Wildlife Area starting in October.
Description 2: The most common duck visitors are the northern pintail and the northern shoveler, but also look for the American widgeon, green-winged teal, canvasback, common goldeneye, and bufflehead. Pintails arrive as early as august, but most birds start arriving in October, peaking in December. They head north again come March and April.
Media Credit: add video of winter waterfowl + consider adding links e.g. https://www.allaboutbirds.org/guide/norsho
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Wintering geese and swans tend to arrive in November, with over 10,000 snow geese and greater white-fronted geese visiting each season.
Description 2: Tule white-fronted geese, ross's geese, and tundra swans also visit. Geese arrive from as far north as Banks Island in the Arctic Archipelago and Wrangel Island off the north coast of Russia.
Media Credit: photo of swans with sacramento in the bkg
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Other waterfowl stay closer to home.
Description 2: Birds like the coot, mallard, gadwall, and cinnamon teal --along with some shovelers-- nest at the Wildlife Area during the summer. Look for broods of ducklings on the permanent ponds in May through July.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Great blue herons, great egrets, snowy egrets, American bitterns and white pelicans, can also be found in the Wildlife Area year-round.
Waders like the white-faced ibis nest in the tule marsh over the summer and forage in the rice fields in the fall.
Many shorebirds (including avocets, black-necked stilts, killdeer, and coots) nest in the wildlife area in April.
Description 2: Chicks appear in May.

Description: Other shorebirds (including black-bellied plovers, greater yellowlegs, and long-billed dowitchers) head north in April to nest, returning to the wildlife area mid-summer.

Still others (phalaropes, willets, godwits, and some sandpipers) use the Wildlife Area as a stop on their migration to their northern summer breeding grounds, visiting in both the spring and late fall.
Look among the tangle of tule and cattails for red-winged blackbird, marsh wren, and rails like the Virginia rail and sora.
The grassland ecosystems host western meadowlark, yellow-billed magpie, and tree swallows.
Birds of prey include the red-tailed hawk, swainson's hawk, and northern harrier.
Description 2: Swainson's hawks arrive from the South in April to nest, staying through September, while other raptors can be spotted year-round.

Description: ...and check the trees for great horned owls!
